title: ISTH-SCC Bleeding Assessment Tool
description: Assesses bleeding symptoms in patients with inherited bleeding disorders. This standardized questionnaire was developed by the International Society on Thrombosis and Haemostasis (ISTH) Scientific and Standardization Committee (SSC) to evaluate 14 different bleeding symptoms and identify patients who may have inherited bleeding disorders requiring further investigation.

parameters.name: cutaneous_bleeding
parameters.description: Skin bleeding including bruising and petechiae

parameters.name: minor_wounds
parameters.description: Bleeding from minor wounds and cuts

parameters.name: oral_cavity
parameters.description: Bleeding from gums and oral cavity

parameters.name: postpartum_hemorrhage
parameters.description: Bleeding after childbirth (applicable to females with delivery history)

parameters.name: cns_bleeding
parameters.description: Central nervous system bleeding (special scoring: never=0, subdural=3, intracerebral=4)

parameters.name: other_bleeding
parameters.description: Other bleeding symptoms not covered above

parameters.name: age_group
parameters.description: Patient age group for interpretation thresholds

result.name: bleeding_score
result.description: Total ISTH-SCC bleeding assessment score (0-55 points maximum)

ranges.interpretation: Score 0-2 points for children <18 years: Typical bleeding pattern. Low likelihood of inherited bleeding disorder. Consider clinical context and family history.
Score ≥3 points for children <18 years: Atypical bleeding pattern. Increased likelihood of inherited bleeding disorder. Consider hematologic evaluation and laboratory testing.

ranges.description: Typical bleeding pattern for adult males
ranges.interpretation: Score 0-3 points for adult males: Typical bleeding pattern. Low likelihood of inherited bleeding disorder. Consider clinical context and family history.

ranges.description: Atypical bleeding pattern for adult males
ranges.interpretation: Score ≥4 points for adult males: Atypical bleeding pattern. Increased likelihood of inherited bleeding disorder. Consider hematologic evaluation and laboratory testing.

ranges.description: Typical bleeding pattern for adult females
ranges.interpretation: Score 0-5 points for adult females: Typical bleeding pattern. Low likelihood of inherited bleeding disorder. Consider clinical context and family history.

ranges.description: Atypical bleeding pattern for adult females
ranges.interpretation: Score ≥6 points for adult females: Atypical bleeding pattern. Increased likelihood of inherited bleeding disorder. Consider hematologic evaluation including von Willebrand disease and platelet function studies.

references: Rodeghiero F, Tosetto A, Abshire T, Arnold DM, Coller B, James P, Neunert C, Lillicrap D. ISTH/SSC bleeding assessment tool: a standardized questionnaire and a proposal for a new bleeding score for inherited bleeding disorders. J Thromb Haemost. 2010 Sep;8(9):2063-5.

Deforest M, Grabell J, Albert S, Young E, Tuttle A, Hopman WM, Heddle N, James PD. Generation and optimization of the self-administered bleeding assessment tool and its validation as a screening test for von Willebrand disease. Haemophilia. 2015 May;21(3):e132-9.

Quiroga T, Goycoolea M, Panes O, Aranda E, Martínez C, Belmont S, Muñoz B, Zúñiga P, Pereira J, Mezzano D. High prevalence of bleeders of unknown cause among patients with inherited mucocutaneous bleeding. A prospective study of 280 patients and 299 controls. Haematologica. 2007 Mar;92(3):357-65.
formula: Sum of all 14 bleeding variable scores (0-4 points each, except CNS bleeding with 0/3/4 scoring)
notes: Designed for patients with suspected inherited bleeding disorders
Score only bleeding symptoms present BEFORE and AT diagnosis
Distinction between score 0 (no/trivial bleeding) and 1+ is critical
Different thresholds for children (<18 years), adult males, and adult females
Requires trained assessor (physician or health professional) for reliability
Tool is relatively insensitive for children with possible inherited bleeding disorders
Useful for screening but not diagnostic - laboratory testing required for confirmation
Consider family history and clinical context in interpretation
